name: Video Codec & Compression
description: Sector template for video compression and codec patents including H.264/AVC, HEVC/H.265, VVC, AV1, and related encoding/decoding technologies.
contextDescription: Video codec patents cover the core compression technologies used in streaming, broadcast, and recording. Key areas include motion estimation/compensation, transform coding (DCT, DST), entropy coding (CABAC, CAVLC), loop filtering, intra/inter prediction, and rate control. Standards include H.264/AVC, HEVC/H.265, VVC/H.266, VP9, and AV1. Patent value often correlates with standards essentiality and adoption breadth.
scoringGuidance: Patents covering mandatory decoder operations (entropy decoding, motion compensation) are high value due to unavoidable infringement.
CABAC/entropy coding optimizations are computational bottlenecks - hardware implementations are valuable.
Standards-essential patents (H.264, HEVC, VVC) have higher licensing potential than proprietary codecs.
AV1/royalty-free codec patents may have defensive value against standard-essential assertions.
Look for patents that span multiple codec generations (techniques applicable to H.264 through VVC).

questions.question: Which video codec generation(s) does this patent apply to? Score 1-3 for legacy only (MPEG-2, H.263), 4-6 for current mainstream (H.264/AVC, VP9), 7-10 for modern/next-gen (HEVC, VVC, AV1) or multi-generational applicability.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify the codec standard(s) and assess current/future relevance. Multi-generational techniques score higher.

questions.question: What compression component does this patent address? Consider: motion estimation/compensation, transform coding, quantization, entropy coding (CABAC/CAVLC), loop filtering, intra prediction, rate control.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify the specific codec component. Score based on how fundamental/unavoidable the component is in typical implementations.

questions.question: How likely is this patent to be essential to a video coding standard? Score 1-3 for non-essential/alternative approach, 4-6 for potentially essential, 7-10 for likely essential to standard compliance.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess whether the technique is required by H.264, HEVC, VVC, or AV1 specifications. Consider decoder-side requirements.

questions.question: Is this patent applicable to hardware implementations, software implementations, or both? Score 1-3 for software-only, 4-6 for hardware-focused, 7-10 for both or specifically targeting hardware acceleration.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Hardware codec implementations in mobile SoCs and GPUs are high-value targets. Identify implementation applicability.

questions.question: Does this patent apply to encoding, decoding, or both? Score 1-4 for encoder-only, 5-7 for decoder-only, 8-10 for both or decoder-mandatory operations.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Decoder patents have broader infringement scope (every device with video playback). Encoder patents target content creators/platforms.
